author: @B_Estes_Undeg√∂etz
text: Marxism doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúneed‚Äù any of those people. This video crosses a line that matters for anyone serious about Marxism-Leninism and materialism and the historical and dialectical materialist analysis. Presenting Heidegger, Dugin, ≈Ωi≈æek, Lacan, or figures like Haz al-Din as ‚Äúneeded‚Äù by Marxism isn‚Äôt an update or enrichment‚Äîit‚Äôs a substitution. Marxism doesn‚Äôt lack ontology, psychoanalysis, civilizational theory, or metaphysical depth; it is a materialist analysis of labor, production, class, and imperialism oriented toward disciplined materialist economic class organization and power. When these other frameworks are introduced as ‚Äúnecessary‚Äù supplements, what disappears is political economy, discipline, and the primacy of class relations. Haz al-Din‚Äôs contribution here is affect and posture, not material analysis, and Midwestern Marx‚Äôs endorsement of this stuff confirms a broader pattern on the channel: Marxism is being reshaped into a loose anti-liberal synthesis that abandons Marxism-Leninism‚Äôs core commitments. This isn‚Äôt development‚Äîit‚Äôs revisionist drift, and viewers should understand that none of this is required to follow the real Marxist path.  This is social media hype substituting for organization, political economy, and disciplined revolutionary Marxist-Leninism‚Äîby turning Marxism into personality, posture, and algorithm-friendly idealist and philosophy theory mashups.

replies.author: @borism2766
replies.text:
The three "dimensions" in question are the dimension of the imaginary (a mirror dimension or stage in the development of the subject), the symbolic dimension, and the dimension of the real (not to be confused with reality.
Let me explain this using the example of the NATO alliance.
The member countries of the NATO alliance see themselves (in the mirror) as members of a defense alliance - this is the imaginary dimension.
In the symbolic dimension, they exchange symbolic "mandates" with each other. Namely, this is where it is determined who is "daddy" among them.
The dimension of the real in psychoanalysis is the dimension of the torsion of the symbolic. The dimension of something that constantly returns (the repressed).
When we talk about the NATO alliance, it is convenient to note that the member countries of that alliance are simultaneously nation states with unconquered mutual animosities. Greece / Turkey; Germany / France; England / France; "old Europe" / "new Europe" .....
In other words, the NATO alliance is a bag full of horns in the dimension of the real.

We we are trying to be Marxists here, so I add a "fourth dimension", and say that when it comes to NATO, the bag is actually made of paper. (Lacan avec Mao) -

replies.text:
Heidegger would later reflect in the Turn that Being and Time didn‚Äôt work as he had intended, not because he was wrong, but because it was still being understood through the very framework of Subjectivity he was trying to annihilate. The critique to the origin of metaphysics hadn‚Äôt gone far enough, so the question of ‚Äúwhat is Being‚Äù was interpreted through the logic of the Cartesian Subject and metaphysics that he was trying to confront.

Metaphysics as such is structurally flawed because it always ‚Äúputs the world into picture.‚Äù That logic turns Being into something to be complete defined, enclosed and solved, which is why Being and Time was taken up as a sort of existential psychology or a theory of the Subject instead of a break from that whole school of Metaphysics. 

Heidegger himself was part of his time and history, and in that moment, the Nazi Party presented itself as the historic destiny of the historic German people, just as Liberalism had for the English and Bolshevism for Russians. Heidegger mistook a political movement for something deeper than it was, confusing a historical socialist organization with a supposed answer to the crisis of modernity, and only later came to see that this confusion followed from the same flawed metaphysics he was trying to escape.

author: @matthewkopp2391
text:
I don‚Äôt agree. I appreciate Marx trying to materialize liberal ideology, meaning making a tangible assessment of the ideology. Marx also proposed that only certain things are possible in certain historical conditions.

Heidegger‚Äòs flaw is understanding ontology only within a structural frame. This lead him into the belief that Nazism could lead to ontological fulfillment.

Ontology is the study of being. IMO ancient religious ideas actually deal with ontology in a far more sophisticated way than modernists do. The problem with religion is it becomes dogmatic and the meaning needs to be re-evaluated perennially.

Does anyone know the totality of their own being. No. Of being itself? No. The ground of being. No Religion assigns this to ‚ÄûGod‚Äú or ‚ÄûAtman‚Äú etc. the ultimate.

Our full ontology is ineffable. It can exist under any circumstances. Adverse circumstances is only an excuse, we can access it regardless of historical circumstances and strive towards it.

Wishing for a totalitarian society in the hopes of fullness of being is delusional.

I can agree with the pragmatism of Marx but not the delusions of Heidegger.

replies.text:
@wtfhah
That‚Äôs interesting. I agree. I think Haz has contributed much to Marxism-Leninism in the U.S. and the West in general, and a lot of this exactly because of his willingness to practical and theoretical exploration and experimentation.
That said, I chose the word idiosyncratic because wanted to keep it neutral (I could say original/innovative for positive connotations and deviant/heretic for more negative ones). I do think it is idiosyncratic, for better or for worse. I don‚Äôt think anyone before him incorporates Heidegger, Dugin and Plato into his Marxist understanding of the world. ≈Ωi≈æek is an easy target for Marxist-Leninists, but Haz still finds value in some of his thoughts even though he‚Äôs aware of his weaknesses.

I haven‚Äôt explored sufficiently what actual value Haz finds in these thinkers, and I haven‚Äôt actually studied any of these thinkers myself almost at all. I remain open, absolutely, and willing to explore more! But I have to admit that I‚Äôm also a bit skeptical.
I have read enough of Marx, Engels and Lenin and certain Chinese Communists [including the CPC which doesn‚Äôt allow religious affiliation if you are to become a member of the CPC] to know that religion, though fully tolerated and respected outside party organization, has been seen as incompatible with dialectical materialism. And I have seen nothing in the works of the greatest Marxists any big focus on Plato (and Heidegger when it comes to Stalin and Mao among others).
But again, maybe Haz is adapting it to ‚ÄúMarxism with Western characteristics‚Äù / ‚Äúwesternized Marxism‚Äù.
Even though I may end up supporting and defending Haz‚Äôs understanding, now I‚Äôm quite skeptical of his attachment to religion, and thereby probably also his interpretation of what materialism is. But I know that I don‚Äôt know enough about it.

What do you think?

author: @Chicane-mx5xb
text: Haz got a (disparaging but regardless) shout out in a footnote for zizeks new book (Quantum History). On that topic, I dispute zizek privileging philosophy as closer to reality or more authentic. Especially in Sex and The Failed Absolute, the chapter on the four ethical gestures is about moving beyond the immediate authentic reaction of alienation(which is what is really privileged by most lacanians) to something potentially intersubjective or political. What is important is that this myth making remains in contact with its alienated (non)grounding. So a more practical example from the new book(chapter title "holograms of conflicting universalities"): Zizek goes into russias past in order to reread the Old Believers(purged by the bolsheviks as an obsolete form of social resistance to the tsars) as pointing towards a new "conservative communist" future that is both against putin without backsliding into pre-putin liberal russia. But our ability to make these interpretive maneuvers mean that we are never free from history as a struggle, matters(beings) are never settled, we are always circulating around our(and the universal's) alienation from itself.
